Package ws.rocket.path.annotation

Annotation-based approach for describing a tree so that it could be composed at runtime (on demand) using CDI ( Contexts and Dependency Injection) mechanism.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    KeyBuilder
    Contract for annotated tree node value objects wishing to construct their own tree node key manually.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    RootNodeProducer
    CDI (Contexts And Dependency Injection) producer creating root TreeNodes.
  • Annotation Types Summary 
    Annotation Type Description
    RootNode
    CDI qualifying annotation, which triggers a tree construction where the root node value is with provided name or type.
    TreeNode
    Annotation used on TreeNode values (classes) for describing the node to be constructed where the annotated value object will belong to.

Package ws.rocket.path.annotation Description

Annotation-based approach for describing a tree so that it could be composed at runtime (on demand) using CDI ( Contexts and Dependency Injection) mechanism.

This approach for composing a tree is provided as an alternative and is not mandatory. It might not even suit for all needs. For example, this approach requires each tree node to have a value object (as its class must be annotated). However, this annotation-based method for constructing the tree could be simple and well enough for most cases.

Tree is constructed when CDI encounters a dependency injection point (field, parameter) with TreeNode type and with RootNode annotation. The annotation refers to the value bean of the root tree node: 

 @Inject
 @RootNode("root")
 private TreeNode root;

RootNodeProducer uses the data (CDI bean name or type) from RootNode annotation to search for the value bean of the root node. An example of a bean, which will become the value of a tree node, is following (complementing the previous sample): 

 @Named("root")
 @TreeNode(childNames = { "child1", "child2" })
 public class Root implements KeyBuilder {

   public Object buildKey() {
     return KeysFactory.root();
   }
 }

The previous code sample for a node value illustrates many features but let's look at them individually:

  1. the CDI @Named annotation is used so that the bean could be referred by name;
  2. the @TreeNode annotation is used for describing the values belonging to child-nodes (so there will be 2 child-nodes in this example, and with the same order).
  3. the class optionally implements KeyBuilder contract to create a more sophisticated key for its TreeNode. Otherwise, the @TreeNode could be used instead (though, the interfaces ought to be removed then as it takes precedence).

When a node value object implements TreeNodeBuilderAware contract, it will override annotations on the same class.

Each annotation supports referring to classes either by CDI bean name(s) or Java class(es). Both methods have their pros and cons, however, they cannot be mixed in one annotation declaration. When unsure, referring by class could be preferred as it is less vulnerable to code refactoring (e.g. when renaming a class).
